title: The Anivia changes feel absolutely awful to play.
body:
Is it just me or does the ult change feel so clunky? Like I know that it was unhealthy to have the instant ult-e, but they didnt give the ult any more power besides a bigger slow and growing to the same size it was before after a few seconds. 

Also, the ult doesnt even feel like it casts anymore. When i cast it, it just doesnt *feel* like i did anything, and from a gameplay perspective this is pretty bad to have.

Edit: Also, shouldn't riot have at least increased ult cast range? It effectively decreased her ult-e range by so much.

replies.body: eh tbh its fine she just the same other than her ultimate growing.. tho i would have prefered if they increased the range of it again and the slow in it
Yeah, the reduced size of her ult effectively reduces the range of her ult-e combo

Which sure, her E combo is incredibly strong.

But that is literally how you play Anivia, that's how you have ALWAYS played Anivia. Without it, you're just a utility mage with a wall every 20 seconds, and a stun/slow that isn't difficult to dodge once everyone has 80000 movement speed, especially now.

Immobile (anivia)

Example if you cast Q in a full charged R it grows in size and distance it can go when traveling through her R, still able to detonate it at any time

But you should also keep in mind that even an Anivia who is ahead has still some very obvious weaknesses.
She is still very vulnerable to ganks and not very good at roaming herself. 
This limits even a fed Anivia more or less to one single lane, which she can't even push very hard due to the lack of an escape mechanism.
So opressive maybe, but not overwhelming in the way other mid-laners might be.

Also... Any champ is difficult to play against, if he is ahead. Anything else would be odd.

Yes champs can be difficult to play against if ahead but anivia is insanely hard to fight when she's fed, unless you have the jgler come (that applies to shutting down any fed character). She's also quite feast and famine.

But you should also keep in mind that even an Anivia who is ahead has still some very obvious weaknesses.
She is still very vulnerable to ganks and not very good at roaming herself.

It's like a fed Lux/Brand/Velkoz. They don't have escapes, and are squishy, they both roam as well, but most of them(pre-rework, I can't judge them postrework yet) have  not been oppressive when fed. They both have waveclear on scale of Anivia's R+Q(You may say burning Anivia's Q gets rid of her form of selfPeel, but Vel and Lux do you use their cc abilities as well. Brand doesn't use his cc ability, but he requires his other abilities off cooldown to land it, but he uses W+E to waveclear quickly.

Except maybe Lux.

I don't think you really understood what I was trying to say.

Anivia can't risk pushing a minion wave too hard, even if she is ahead. So what does this mean for her opponent? 

1) Control you wave and try to freeze it on your side of the lane. It will make Anivia very careful on how to use her skills. She will use her Q much more sparingly and just flying up to R-E someone is a bigger risk.

2) Roam yourself. Anivia will often prefer to stay on the lane, which means you will have advantage in numbers most of the time. 
You might even consider switching lanes with your bot.
It forces Anivia to either deal with two people at a time or to switch to bot herself. The longer lanes are usually uncomfortable for the bird, and will give you more room to control your wave.

3) Recall / Back off when you have to. Anivia is usually not able to one-shot you with one combo, nor will she chase you very hard. So if you take too much damage, walk away. It's pretty easy to not feed Anivia in the first place. Yes she might out-farm you, but worse things have happened.

Yes, Anivia can push. All mages can push with their waveclear, make the opponent lose XP, and do dmg whenever the opponent tries to farm.

You should just try to push the lane as the opponent freezes it, or use RE whenever they want to last hit.

No she doesn't need to use her q that sparingly, she just doesn't need to be stupid and go charging in like a Sion. She's got range. 

The "roam" is the same thing that applies to any other mage. Any other mage can roam when ahead, even anivia. 

Switching with bot will probably get you killed by the opponents 2v1.
Especially if you are melee.

Yes exactly, she outfarms you, outdmgs you, outranges you, pushes the lane really quickly with her R, before roaming or recalling or whatnot.

Please do read what I wrote before answering.
Of course she can push - but she will be in a very vulnerable position, if she does. Any good jungler will exploit on that.

And to have some measure of safety she won't use the Q so much, as it can save her from a gank.

Anivia won't roam much. She isn't good at it, since she is very slow.
 YOU however are supposed to roam, when loosing lane against her.

Switch with top then, if it makes you any happier. Some people also manage to lane against two.

And if she does all of that, then it's another hint that you should 
1) leave lane
2) not feed her in the first place, because that is really not so hard.

Level 7-9 ER does ~30-50% hp, depending on enemy base HP, whether they have MR glyphs, ect.

For example, level 7 30 AP, E~ 320 raw + ~130 dmg from R (3 ticks) + ~75 thunderlords = 525 damage. Vs Ahri, 902 HP, 17 effective MR (30 less mpen marks and  mastery) equals ~449 effective damage, or around 49% of her max health. This doesn't factor oppression bonus damage, which you ofc get, or assassin if you chose to take it.

Q is level 2 by level 6, you don't take wall until level 8 in most matchups. So it add(ed) 210, plus 87 more from ultimate, so 824 raw dmg, or 704 effective damage. Around 78% of her health. 

This assumes armor seals and either AP, AP/lvl, or CDR glyphs, but even with HP/lvl and MR glyphs, the numbers are still well within the range I gave. Try it with other champs if you want, but Ahri's fairly representative and very common.

Anivia is a CONTROL MAGE, this means she excels at controlling a certain territory which is very related to her lore about how she is the protector of the Frejord.
Anivia is very dominant in a certain area but struggles to control the next area since her Q is very unreliable to land at long range and her primary damage E a lot shorter than other mages.

Anivia's AA speed is increased which is a blessing. It will let noobs last hit better early game.

Her Q deserved to get a little nerf in damage since a 1.0 ratio on 2 abilities is very strong. However it should be rewarding to land it since it is a very risky spell to use which could leave you defenseless. The Stun duration is increased which is fair.
W is the same.
E is nerfed because it has a faster animation. This means you need to be a lot quicker to land you E>R combo or E>Q combo. Most of the time, you will probably see people do the R>E Combo or Q>E.

Now her Ult.
It does not control ANYTHING except the same range as a melee minion.
Anivia now struggles to wave clear which will end up in loss of CS and setting your laning behind POST 6. It was already difficult to last hit before 6 because most mid laners can pressure you extremely well while you only have Q to defend yourself.
The comment, "Her ult is going to be soooooooooooooo good in teamfights." 
If you are going to have a teamfight that stays in the same spot for 3 seconds then sure but since every champ has mobility or gives insane mobility to allies, this 3 second is pointless. It would have the same impact as if her ult charged up over a 50 second interval.

Some aspects of the changes just reward mediocrity. [STRICTLY AN OPINION]:

A good Anivia doesn't need a longer stun time or a longer E cast range. Even increasing the projectile speed for the E eliminates play styles that involve casting it first before procing the ult, or following it up right behind a Q. 

The ult was traditionally used to safely harass from a distance post level 6 in lane, because kills were only achievable on her own by the enemy either getting poked down by R-E/E-R combos or falling prey to getting hard CC'ed by a Q, after which the full combo was unleashed and lethal.  At level 6, almost every common mid, reworked or not, has an ultimate that directly assists in the burst/nuke of the enemy laner down to death. 

Anivia's ult served as a tool to ACTIVELY trade with mid laners who could best her at close range with their CC. It also provided CONTROL by means of creating a zone where MS and AS are both inhibited. YES, I agree the damage amounts for the E with the ult/Q proc are large, but at the same time it comes at the cost of horrendous mana consumption, her lack of mobility, susceptibility to being ganked, as well as the E being entirely dependant on getting that proc for any reasonable damage to be dealt. 

If Riot wants her to be a zone control mage, then why inhibit the core element of her zoning capabilities, yet have a blind eye to huge amounts of burst damage her E gets when proc'ed with ult or Q? TBH a power reduction for how much damage the E does after frost is applied could have been enough to satisfy people wailing about how OP her burst is when she is ahead.

This rework (NERF) makes Anivia  dependant on landing that Q, which was furthermore dependant on the ult that ZONED them into it or slowed them into getting hit by it. Sure, someone can get close enough to activate the center of the ult onto the enemy laner, but good luck coming out alive because you will be instantly CC'ed/bursted before you can combo anything. 

The ultimate, as it stands now, will rarely see use of the massive MS reduction and 50% damage increase at max size because team fights are so dynamic and mobile. It is now strictly situational to instances where people fight at a turret/dragon/baron, but even then how often do people really sit in that small area when fighting?
